questions.text: Pseudopapillitis is seen in ?
questions.solution:
Pseudopapillitis is seen in fundus examination of a hypermetropic eye.

It reveals

  • A small optic disc
  • May look more vascular with ill defined margins
  • No swelling of the disc

Hypermetropia -  long sightedness - is the refractive state of the eye wherein parallel rays of light coming from infinity are focused behind the retina with accomodation being at rest.

Signs:

  • Size of eyeball - small.
  • Cornea may be slightly smaller.
  • Short antero-posterior length of the eyeball.
  • Fundus picture:
    • Pseudopapillitis
    • The retina as a whole may shine due to greater brilliance of light reflections - shot silk appearance.

Rx:

Convex lens is used for correction (plus lens)

questions.text: You prescribe oral rehydration solution (ORS) to a child brought to the outpatient department with complaints of loose stools. ORS facilitates glucose absorption through sodium-dependent glucose co-transporter-1 (SGLT-1). This glucose co-transport with sodium ions is an example of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Glucose co-transported with sodium is an example of secondary active transport.

Transporting more than one substance together using a single transport protein against the gradient is known as secondary active transport. As one of the substances (e.g., sodium) diffuses down its electrochemical gradient, energy is released, which is used to drive another substance (e.g., glucose) against the gradient. Thus, secondary active transport does not require energy directly from ATP.
 
Sodium ions are transported out of cells by primary active transport, resulting in a large concentration gradient across the cell membrane. This gradient represents a storehouse of energy, which is used by sodium to pull glucose along with it using the SGLT-1 transporter. This phenomenon, called co- transport, is one form of secondary active transport. 

Types of transport:

  • Active transport
    • Primary
      • Energy is derived from ATP.
      • Example: Na+ K+ ATPase pump.
    • Secondary:
      • Energy is derived indirectly (ion gradient).
      • Example: Sodium linked glucose transport in kidneys and intestine, Sodium linked iodine transport
  • Passive transport
    • Simple:
      • No energy is required.
      • No carrier molecule is involved.
      • Eg. O2 exchange in alveoli.
    • Facilitated:
      • No energy is required.
      • Carrier molecule involved.
      • Eg. Glucose transport by GLUT transporters.

Related Pearl: Characteristics of different types of transport

questions.text: Artery which doesn’t contribute to formation of Kiesselbach’s plexus is
questions.solution:
The posterior ethmoidal artery does not contribute to the formation of Kiesselbach’s plexus.

Kiesselbach’s plexus is the vascular anastomosis formed in Little’s area. It is situated in the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum, just above the nasal vestibule. It is the most common site of epistaxis in children and young adults.

The arteries contributing to it are:

    • Sphenopalatine and greater palatine branches of the maxillary artery which in turn is a branch of the external carotid artery.
    • Septal branch of the superior labial artery which in turn is a branch of the facial artery. The facial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery.
    • Anterior ethmoidal branch of the ophthalmic division of the internal carotid artery.

The posterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the ophthalmic division of the internal carotid artery which supplies the nasal septum but doesn’t contribute to Kiesselbach’s plexus.

questions.text: Level of residual chlorine after one hour is
questions.solution:
The level of residual chlorine after one hour is 0.5 mg/L.

  • The presence of free residual chlorine for a contact period of at least one hour is essential to kill bacteria and viruses.

questions.text: A 35-year-old gentleman presents to the clinic with bloody diarrhea, tenesmus, and crampy abdominal pain for the past week. The colonoscopy image is given below. Which of the following is commonly not associated with the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the endoscopic image point to a diagnosis of ulcerative colitis. Urethritis is not an extraintestinal manifestation of ulcerative colitis.

Ulcerative colitis is characterized by recurring episodes of inflammation limited to the mucosa of the colon and rectum. It presents with chronic diarrhea, tenesmus, mucus and blood passage per rectum, and crampy abdominal pain.

Sigmoidoscopy shows severe colon inflammation with erythema, friability, and exudates. Active disease is associated with a rise in acute-phase reactants (C-reactive protein), platelet count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), and a decrease in hemoglobin. Diagnosis is based on the patient’s clinical symptoms, sigmoidoscopic appearance, and histology of rectal or colonic biopsy specimens.

Extraintestinal manifestations of ulcerative colitis 

  • Musculoskeletal -
    • Arthritis
    • Sacroiliitis
    • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Eye -
    • Uveitis/Iritis
    • Episcleritis
  •  Skin -
    • Erythema nodosum
    • Pyoderma gangrenosum
  • Hepatobiliary -
    • Primary sclerosing cholangitis
    • Fatty liver
    • Cholelithiasis
  • Hematopoietic/coagulation -
    • Venous and arterial thromboembolism
  • Cardiopulmonary -
    • Interstitial lung disease
    • pleuropericarditis
    • endocarditis
    • myocarditis
  • Urologic -
    • Calculi
    • Ureteral obstruction
    • Ileal bladder fistula

questions.text: Studdiford’s criteria is for
questions.solution:
Studdiford laid down the criteria for diagnosis of primary abdominal pregnancy.

It includes:

  • Both the tubes and ovaries are normal without evidence of recent injury.
  • Absence of uteroperitoneal fistula.
  • Presence of a pregnancy related exclusively to the peritoneal surface and young enough to eliminate the possibility of secondary implantation following primary nidation in the tube.

Option A:

Rubin's criteria is used for diagnosis of cervical pregnancy.

 It includes:

  • Soft, enlarged cervix equal to or larger than the fundus.
  • Uterine bleeding following amenorrhea, without cramping pain.
  • Products of conception entirely confined within and firmly attached to endocervix.
  • A closed internal cervical os and a partially opened external os.

Option D:

Spiegelberg's criteria is used for diagnosis of ovarian pregnancy.

It includes

  • Tube on the affected side must be intact.
  • The gestation sac must be in the position of the ovary.
  • The gestation sac is connected to the uterus by the ovarian ligament.
  • The ovarian tissue must be found on its wall on histological examination.

questions.text: All are true about the cartilage shown below EXCEPT?

choices.text: Forms the skeleton of the fetus
Costal cartilage at the end of the ribs is of this type
Ear pinna cartilage is of this type

questions.solution:
The given histopathological image is of Hyaline cartilage.

Ear pinna is made up of Elastic cartilage.

Hyaline Cartilage:

  • Groups of cartilage cells are called cell-nests (or isogenous cell groups)
  • The deep staining matrix immediately surrounding the chondrocytes is called the territorial matrix or lacunar capsule.
  • The pale staining matrix separating cell nests is the interstitial matrix.
  • Most abundant type of cartilage.
  • Forms the skeleton of the fetus (a template of the bones).
  • Endochondral ossification occurs during the childhood, replacing the hyaline cartilage with bone.
  • Hyaline cartilage forms the epiphyseal growth plate and articular surface on bones. 
  • The rings of the Trachea, Costal cartilage at the end of the ribs are hyaline cartilage.

questions.text: In a village having a population of 5000, a diagnostic test for a particular disease showed the following results. What is the prevalence of the disease ?
questions.solution:
The prevalence of the disease in above scenario is 30%.

  • Prevalence includes both old and new cases in its measurement.
  • In this scenario, total number of diseases cases is 1500 and total population at risk is 5000, thus making the prevalence 30%.

 

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: Shirodkar’s stitch for proven case of cervical incompetence is done at
questions.solution:
Shirodkar stitch used in cerclage operation of cervical incompetence is done around 12-14 weeks for a proven case.

Management of cervical incompetence:

  • Principle of cerclage operations:
    • Reinforcing the weak cervix by a nonabsorbable tape, placed around the cervix at the level of internal os.
  • Emergency cerclage operation (Wurm’s operation)
    • It is done when cervix is more than 2 cm dilated with bulging bag of membranes.
  • Prophylactic cerclage (proven case of cervical incompetence) –
    • 2 types of surgeries are done – Mc Donald’s and Shirodkar’s.
  • Prophylactic cerclage is done at around 14 weeks of pregnancy or at least 2 weeks earlier than the lowest period of previous wastage.
  • Surgery between 12-14 weeks allows early intervention yet avoids surgery in a woman with inevitable pregnancy loss in first trimester. Hence the procedure is not performed before this period.
  • Women with singleton pregnancy, prior preterm birth, and a short cervical length (eg, <25 mm) on transvaginal ultrasound examination at 16 to 23 weeks of gestation are potential candidates for an ‘ultrasound-indicated’ cerclage.
  • Women with cervical insufficiency based on a dilated cervix on a digital or speculum examination at 16 to 23 weeks of gestation are potential candidates for a ‘physical exam-indicated’ cerclage.

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics is not used in the treatment of H.pylori infection
questions.solution:
Ciprofloxacin is not used in the treatment of H.pylori infection.

Amoxicillin, clarithromycin, metronidazole and tetracycline are the antibiotics used in the treatment of H.pylori infection.

Treatment of H.pylori infection:

In low clarithromycin resistance areas

  • Clarithromycin 500mg
  • Amoxycillin 1000mg (metronidazole 500mg in case of penicillin allergy)        
  • Lansoprazole 30 mg

All the above Twice daily × 14 days

In high clarithromycin resistance areas

  • Bismuth subcitrate 120mg QID
  • Tetracyclin 500mg QID
  • Metronidazole 500mg TDS                 
  • Lansoprazole 30 mg BD

All the above for 14 days

questions.text: Which of the following is an anti-inflammatory cytokine?
questions.solution:
IL-4 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine.

It induces alternatively activated macrophages. This results in tissue repair and the resolution of inflammation.

The following are anti-inflammatory cytokines:

  • IL-4
  • IL-10
  • IL-13
  • TGF-β
  • Lipoxins

Lipoxins suppress inflammation by inhibiting leukocyte recruitment. They inhibit neutrophil chemotaxis and adhesion to endothelium.

Related Pearl: Cytokines

IL-2 T cells
IL-3 T cells
IL-4 TH cells
IL-5 TH cells
IL-6 TH, macrophages, fibroblasts
IL-8 Macrophages, others
IL-10 T, B cells, macrophages

Pro-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-1: induces inﬂammation, fever, and sepsis, activates TNF-α; proliferation and differentiation of T, B, and other cells; bone marrow cell proliferation
  • IL-2: promote growth and differentiation of T and B cells; cytotoxicity of T and NK cells; secretion of other lymphokines
  • IL-6: promote B cell stimulation & differentiation; mediator of acute phase reactions; IgG production
  • IL-8: attracts and activates neutrophils in inflammatory regions; neutrophil chemotaxis
  • IFN-α: antiviral, immunoregulatory (enhance MHC class I, NK-cell activity), antiproliferative
  • TNF-α: activate macrophages and cytotoxic cells, induce cachexia, acute phase proteins, cytokines such as IL-1 and IL-6

Anti-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-4: proliferation of B and cytotoxic cells; increases IgG1 and IgE production; enhances MHC-class II receptor
  • IL-10: inhibits IFN-γ and IL-12 production; inhibits IFN production and mononuclear cell functions
  • IL-13

Acute inflammation and sepsis: 

  • TNF-α
  • IL-1

Special Cytokines: 

  1. IFN-γ: 
    • Granuloma formation
    • Antiviral
    • Immunoregulatory (enhances MHC classes I and II and macrophage activation)
    • Antiproliferative
  2. TGF-β: 
    • Fibrosis 
    • Activate macrophages
  3. VEGF:
    • promotes angiogenesis

questions.text: Which of the following is not an intra-articular fracture
questions.solution:
March fracture is fatigue fracture of shaft of second or third metatarsal. It is not an intra-articular farcture.

Option a:  Rolando fracture is comminuted intra-articular fracture of base of first metacarpal.

Option b: Bennett’s fracture is an oblique intra-articular fracture of the base of first metacarpal with subluxation of trapeziometacarpal joint (unopposed pull of abductor pollicis longus).

Option d: Barton’s fracture is an intra-articular fracture of distal end of radius with subluxation of carpal bones.

questions.text: Danforth sign is seen in

questions.text: Acronym AMBU stands for:
questions.solution:

questions.text: Quinke triad is seen in
questions.solution:
• Quinke triad is seen in case of haemobilia.
  • It is triad of
    • Upper abdominal pain
    • Upper gastrointestinal haemorrhage
    • Jaundice
  • It is seen in only 22% of patients with haemobilia.

Haemobilia:

  • Haemobilia is defined as bleeding into the biliary tree from an abnormal communication between a blood vessel and bile duct.
  • The most common cause of haemobilia is iatrogenic trauma to the liver and biliary tree.
  • The symptoms and signs of major haemobilia are
    • Melena (90% of cases),
    • Haematemesis (60% of cases)
    • Biliary colic (70% of cases)
    • Jaundice (60% of cases)
  • Arterial angiography is the test of choice.
  • Angiographic embolisation is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: Sabin Feldman dye test is done for
questions.solution:

questions.text: A patient of hypoglycaemia fails to regain consciousness even after blood glucose is restored to normal. Which of the following is most likely to have occurred ?

questions.text: The most common clinical sign of Pulmonary embolism is
questions.solution:
Tachypnea is the most common clinical sign present in Pulmonary embolism.

The incidence of symptoms in PE is :

  • Tachypnea ( RR > 16/min ) – 96%
  • Rales – 58%
  • Accentuated heart sound – 53%
  • Tachycardia – ( Heart rate > 100/min ) – 44%
  • Fever – 43%

Pulmonary embolism :

  • Most common cause – Deep vein thrombosis
  • ECG = S1 Q3 T3
  • Chest x ray signs
    • Westermark sign – focal oligemia
    • Palla sign – pulmonary artery dilatation
    • Hampton hump – Wedge shaped opacity
  • Screening test – D dimer test
  • IOC- CT angiography
  • Gold standard – Pulmonary angiography/ VP scan

questions.text: ROME scheme was proposed by which of the following committees ?

questions.text: Unilateral sex linked histocompatibility is known as
questions.solution:
Eichwald-Silmser effect is unilateral sex linked histocompatibility.

  • Graft from female to a male will be successful but graft from male to female will lead to graft rejection.
  • This is because males will have antigens determined by Y chromosome which will be absent in females.

Option b:

Schwartzman reaction – It is a phenomenon related to endotoxin.

  • Clearing of thrombosis resulting from endotoxin will cause reticuloendothelial blockade.
  • On subsequent inoculation of same endotoxin, thrombosis can’t be cleared because of reticuloendothelial blockade.
  • This results in tissue necrosis.

Option c:

Schultz Dale phenomenon –

  • It is a phenomenon where isolated tissues, such as intestinal or uterine muscle strips from sensitized guinea pigs, if held in a bath or Ringer’s solution they contract vigorously on addition of specific antigen to the bath.
  • It is an example of Anaphylaxis in-vitro.

Option d:

Theobald Smith phenomenon –

  • It is a phenomenon where guinea pig which have survived the use for diphtheria antitoxin standardization are more susceptible to subsequent inoculation of horse serum.

questions.text: Bicalutamide is an

questions.text: Cells attain maximum size in which phase of bacterial growth
questions.solution:
Maximum cell size is obtained at the end of lag phase.

Bacterial growth curve:

  • Bacterium is inoculated into a liquid media and bacterial counts are obtained at regular intervals.
  • Growth curve is obtained by plotting bacterial counts against the time.
  • The curve of total count doesn’t show phase of decline except in case of autolytic bacteria.
  Lag phase Log/exponential phase Stationary phase Decline phase
Bacterial division No Yes Yes No
Death of bacteria No No Yes Yes
Total count (living plus dead cells) Flat Raises Raises Flat
Viable count (only living cells) Flat Raises Flat Falls
Special features

Preparatory phase – accumulation of enzymes and metabolites

Maximum size at the end of lag phase

 Small size, uniformly stained, metabolically active Gram variableIntracellular storage granules, sporulation, exotoxin and antibiotic production Involution forms are seen

questions.text: As per “drugs and cosmetics act” prescription drugs are included in
questions.solution:

  • P – Expiry period of drug formulations
  • W – drugs marketed under generic name only
  • X – Psychotropic drugs requiring special license for manufacture and sale
  • Y – Requirements and guidelines on clinical trials, import and manufacture of new drugs

questions.text: Which among the following is the Drug of choice to suppress tics in Tourette syndrome?
questions.solution:
Tetrabenazine is the preferred drug of choice to suppress tics in Tourette syndrome.

Tourette syndrome (TS) is a neurological disorder in children characterized by abnormal involuntary movements called "tics", which can be motor/& vocal.

Treatment is based on severity & association with other disorders (ADHD/OCD). It includes :

  • Non-pharmacological therapy - counseling & behavioral therapy with habit reversal training
  • Pharmacological - Tetrabenazine (preferred), Fluphenazine, Risperidone >> Haloperidol

questions.text: Identify the type of study from the following design:
questions.solution:
The above study design is typical of a Case control study.

  • A case control study uses individuals as the unit.
  • The study proceeds from effect to cause and is done after the exposure and outcome have occurred.
  • This is the first approach to test causal hypothesis and uses controls to support or refute an inference.
  • A nested case control study is a case control study nested in a cohort study and it is a type of cohort study which moves in the forward direction.

questions.text: A young boy presents with skin rashes, acute onset oliguria , CNS manifestations after 5 days of diarrhoea. The diagnosis he is most likely suffering from is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests that the child is suffering from Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura.

Pentad of TTP:

  • Thrombocytopenia leading to bruises or purpura
  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  • CNS symptoms
  • Kidney failure
  • Fever

Note: Hemolytic uremic syndrome presents with the triad of acute renal failure, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: Yoke muscle for left superior rectus is
questions.solution:
Right inferior oblique is the yolk muscle of Left superior rectus.

Yolk muscles are contralateral synergists. They  refers to the pair of muscles  ( one from each eye ) which contract simultaneously during version movements.

So for example, yolk muscle pairs are

  • Right inferior rectus and left superior oblique
  • Left inferior oblique and right superior rectus
  • Right MR and left LR, Right LR and left MR, Right SR and left IO, Right IR and left SO.

questions.text: Which of the following vesicoselective drug doesn’t have hepatic excretion
questions.solution:
Trospium is a vesicoselective drug not having hepatic excretion.

questions.text: False statement about innate immunity is
questions.solution:
Hormones influence innate immunity.

For example :

  • Endocrine disorders like diabetes, hypothyroidism and adrenal dysfunction are associated with enhanced susceptibility to infection.
  • Elevated steroids level during pregnancy is associated with increased susceptibility to infections.

Features of innate immunity:

  • Resistance that an individual possesses by virtue of his or her genetic and constitutional make up.
  • Non specific
  • No prior exposure to antigen required
  • Immune response occurs in minutes
  • No immunological memory
  • It is influenced by age, hormonal factors and nutritional factors

questions.text: A 56 year old man who was diagnosed of gout has been taking allopurinol for the past one year. Which of the following patterns of hepatic injury is caused due to allopurinol?
questions.solution:
• Fibrin ring granuloma is seen in case of allopurinol induced hepatic injury.
  • It is also known as doughnut granuloma.
  • It consists of
    • Central lipid vacuole (appears as central hole since fat is washed out during fixing and staining)
    • Surrounded by fibrin ring
    • Epithelioid macrophages
  • It is also seen in case of Q fever, Hodgkin’s disease, Infectious mononucleosis. 

Other options:

  • Sulfonamides, amiodarone, isoniazid cause noncaseating epitheloid granulomas.
  • Amiodarone and ethanol also cause Steatohepatitis with Mallory-Denk bodies.

questions.text: “Pie in the floor” field defects are seen in:
questions.solution:
• Involvement of the superior fibres (parietal lobe- Bauns loop) of the optic radiations produces an inferior quadrantic hemianopia called “Pie in the Floor”.
  • If the inferior fibres ( temporal lobe – Meyers loop) of the optic radiation are involved, a superior quadrantic hemianopia is produced called “pie in the sky”.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: Among the following, which is the weakest study design to prove causation ?
questions.solution:
Ecological study is the weakest study design to prove causation.

  • Ecological studies take a population as a unit.
  • They provide the weakest evidence for causality because of extrapolation to individuals from regional data.

Option C:

  • Randomized control trials provide the strongest design in this aspect.

Option A and D:

  • Case control and cohort studies have moderate ability to provide evidence for causality

questions.text: A party was attended by 110 people out of which, 40 didn’t eat fruit salad. From the rest of them who ate fruit salad, 55 developed food poisoning. What is the attack rate ?

questions.text: Thiamine acts as a cofactor in
questions.solution:

questions.text: Which among the following matches is true?
questions.solution:
Nazer’s prognostic index is a method to assess the severity of hepatic decompensation in Wilson’s disease in which there is defective copper biliary excretion from liver cells.

Wilsons disease:

  • ATP7B mutation
  • Presence of Kayser Fleischer Ring
  • Most specific investigation – Urinary excretion of copper
  • Gold standard investigation is – Liver biopsy with quantitative copper assays
  • Nazer’s prognostic index: to assess the severity of hepatic decompensation

Other options:

  • Zinc – Stabilises insulin
  • Chromium – Potentiates insulin
  • Selenium deficiency (not toxicity) causes Keshan disease and Kashin - Beck disease

Related Pearl: Nazer’s Prognostic Index

Nazer’s prognostic index for Wilson’s disease

  • Serum bilirubin
  • Serum aspartate aminotransferase (AST)
  • Prolongation of prothrombin time (sec)

Interpretation of Scores :

  • < 7 – Medical therapy
  • 7–9 – Clinical judgement, Either medical / surgical treatment
  • > 9 – Liver transplantation

Wilson's Disease/Chalcosis: Sunflower Cataract

Diabetes mellitus:  Snowflake cataract

Blunt trauma: May present as rosette-shaped cataract

Myotonic dystrophy - Christmas tree cataract

questions.text: The place where the electrode is kept in a cochlear implant is

questions.text: Triplex DNA is due to
questions.solution:
Triplex DNA is due to Hoogsteen pairing

  • Triple stranded DNA is generated by hydrogen bonding of a third strand into major groove of B-DNA.
  • The third strand forms hydrogen bonds with another surface of double helix through so called Hoogsteen pairs.
  • Poly (dA) and Poly (dT) combine to form triple stranded DNA.

questions.text: Alpha feto protein levels are increased in all of the following conditions except
questions.solution:
Alpha fetoprotein is decreased in case of Down’s syndrome.

Alpha feto protein:

  • It is an oncofetal protein (molecular weight 70,000)
  • It is produced by yolk sac and fetal liver
  • Highest level of AFP in fetal serum and amniotic fluid is reached around 13 weeks and thereafter it decreases
  • Maternal serum level reaches a peak around 32 weeks

It is elevated in:

  • Wrong gestational age
  • Open neural tube defects (NTDs)
  • Multiple pregnancy
  • Rh isoimmunization
  • IUFD
  • Anterior abdominal wall defects
  • Renal anomalies

It is decreased in:

  • Trisomies (Down’s syndrome)
  • Gestational trophoblastic disease

questions.text: Spaghetti and meatballs appearance as shown here is characteristic of ?

questions.text: The buccinator muscle is pierced by all, except _______.
questions.solution:
The buccinator muscle is not pierced by the buccal branch of facial nerve. It runs across the muscle and innervates it without piercing it.

  • Insertion – Angle of mouth, Orbicularis oris
  • Structures piercing the buccinator:
    • Parotid duct (Stenson’s duct)
    • Molar mucous glands of buccopharyngeal fascia
    • Buccal branch of mandibular nerve
  • Action:
    • Aids mastication
    • Tenses cheeks in blowing and whistling
    • Aids closure of the mouth

questions.text: Fluctuating level of consciousness is seen in
questions.solution:
Fluctuating level of consciousness is seen in delirium.

Delirium is characterised by the following features:

  • A relatively acute onset,
  • Clouding of consciousness
  • Disorientation
  • Diurnal variation is marked, usually with worsening of symptoms in the evening and night (called sun downing)

 

  • The motor symptoms in include:
    • Asterixis (flapping tremor)
    • Multifocal  myoclonus
    • Carphologia or  floccillation (picking movements at cover-sheets and clothes)
    • Occupational  delirium (elaborate pantomimes/gestures as if continuing their usual occupation in the hospital bed)
    • Tone and reflex abnormalities

Amniocentesis After 15 weeks (early 12–14 weeks)
Cordocentesis 18–20 weeks

questions.text: Spot maps are used for a disease in epidemiology for depiction of:
questions.solution:
Spot maps are used to understand local distributions of a disease.

questions.text: Magistrate inquest is conducted in all except

questions.text: Spalding’s sign is seen in
questions.solution:
Spalding’s sign is seen in maceration.

Maceration is a process of aseptic autolysis occurring after the intrauterine death of a foetus.

Prerequisite: Dead foetus in utero for 3-4 days and surrounded by liquor amnii. Air should be absent.

Important changes in maceration are:

  • Earliest sign – reddening of the skin with peeling (12 hours)
  • Skull bones—loss of alignment and over-riding of bones of cranial vault and overlapping which is seen on radiograph, called as Spalding's sign, due to shrinkage of brain after death; seen within few days of death of foetus
  • Emits a rancid odour
  • Body is soft and pliable and flattens out when placed on even surface
  • Skin—sodden and coppery red/purplish (never greenish as with putrefaction) with blisters, and peeling cuticle
  • Abdomen -  distended
  • Joints abnormally mobile or flexible
  • Organs/viscera—soft and oedematous, lose their morphology, but lungs and uterus remain unaffected for long period

questions.text: A patient with peptic ulcer disease was prescribed ranitidine and sucralfate. The combination is incorrect because

choices.text: Sucralfate interferes with absorption of ranitidine
Combination produces serious adverse effect like agranulocytosis
Ranitidine combines with sucralfate and interferes with its absorption
Ranitidine increases gastric pH so sucralfate is not able to act

questions.solution:
Ranitidine increases gastric pH and hence sucralfate is not able to polymerize as it requires an acidic pH to form a protective layer over the ulcer. Hence it is not a rational combination.

Sucralfate, in an acidic environment (pH < 4) acts by producing a viscous, sticky polymer that adheres to ulcer craters and epithelial cells for up to 6 hours after a single dose. This viscous layer produced in the stomach leads to the inhibition of absorption of other drugs, like phenytoin, digoxin, cimetidine, ketoconazole, and fluoroquinolone antibiotics. 

Constipation is the most common side effect of sucralfate. It should be avoided in patients with renal failure who are at risk of aluminium overload. Aluminium-containing antacids should not be combined with sucralfate in these patients.  As the viscous gel produced by sucralfate is sticky, it may eventually lead to bezoar formation.

It is generally used for prophylaxis of peptic ulcers, but rarely so because its side effects and its risks outweigh its benefits.

questions.text: Corpus luteum function is taken over by placenta at approximately what week of gestation
questions.solution:
Corpus luteum function is taken over by placenta at approximately 8-9 weeks.

Following fertilization, the corpus luteum continues to grow and forms the corpus luteum of pregnancy.

However the corpus luteum of pregnancy is functionally active up to the 10th week in human beings.

Thereafter, the placenta takes over the secretory function and carries preg­nancy to term.

questions.text: Sentinel surveillance is for:
questions.solution:
Sentinel surveillance is supplementary to the normal notification system.

Sentinel Surveillance

questions.text: All of the following are defence against professional negligence except
questions.solution:
Vicarious liability is not a defence against professional negligence.

Vicarious liability(liability for act of another): An employer is responsible not only for his own negligence but also for the negligence of his employees.

Defences Against Negligence

  • No duty owed to the plaintiff
  • Duty discharged according to prevailing standards
  • Misadventure - may be therapeutic, diagnostic and experimental
  • Error of judgement
  • Contributory negligence - absence of ordinary care on the part of the patient or his personal attendant

Option B :

Res judicata (S.300, Cr.P.C.) -

  • If a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a Court in a dispute between the doctor and his patient, the patient will not be allowed to contest the same question.

Option A :

Limitation (Res indicata) -

  • A suit for damages for negligence should be filed against the doctor within two years from the date of alleged negligence. A suit filed after two years will be dismissed.

Morphology: Lacunar variant of RS cell is seen

questions.text: What is the most commonly used Mapleson circuit?
questions.solution:
The most commonly used Mapleson circuit system is Mapleson circuit type D.

Mapleson classified the semi-closed anesthetic breathing system according to

  • The position of the expiratory valve
  • The fresh gas flow inlet
  • Position/presence of the reservoir bag

Mapleson's system includes Type A, B, C, D, E, and F.

Mapleson circuit type D is the circuit of choice for controlled ventilation.

Note: The Bain circuit is a coaxial version of the Mapleson D system that incorporates the fresh gas inlet tubing inside the breathing tube. Bain circuit, unlike Mapleson D, can also be used for spontaneous ventilation.

 

Schimmelbusch mask used for open drop method of anesthesia

Closed or Circle system

Professor William Mapleson (1926-2018), best known for his classification of respiratory circuits was an honorable recipient of Sir Ivan Magill Gold medal in 2002. His recent demise at the age of 92 was one of the greatest loss for the anesthesia community.

questions.text: Post disaster, the WHO recommends which of the following vaccines to be given to the general population ?
questions.solution:
The WHO does not recommend typhoid, cholera or tetanus vaccines for the general population after a disaster.

  • Supply of safe drinking water and proper disposal of excreta are the most practical and effective strategy of preventing diseases, post – disaster.

First rank symptoms can also be seen in:

  • Mania
  • Anxiety
  • Dissociation

(Reference: KAPLAN & SADOCK’S COMPREHENSIVE TEXTBOOK OF PSYCHIATRY, 10th edition, page 3620)

questions.text: You observe the catheter shown in the image being used by your attending in the ICU. Which of the following procedures is it used for?
questions.solution:
The image shown above is the Swan-ganz catheter which is used for pulmonary artery catheterization. It is also called the pulmonary artery catheter. The standard pulmonary artery catheter is 110 cm long with a 7.0 – 9.0 Fr circumference. 

Uses of Swan-ganz catheter:

  • Measurement of pressures in right atrium, right ventricle and pulmonary artery
  • Indirect measurement of left atrial pressure through pulmonary capillary wedge pressure
  • Cardiac output
  • Oxygen saturation- pulmonary samples to rule out left-right shunt
  • Monitoring left ventricle filling pressure
  • Differentiate cardiogenic from non cardiogenic pulmonary edema

questions.text: Angiofibroma might present with any of the presenting features except

choices.text: Serous otitis media and conductive hearing loss

questions.solution:
Angiofibroma causes rhinolalia clausa i.e. denasal voice not rhinolalia aperta.

Clinical features of angiofibroma:

  • Profuse, recurrent and spontaneous epistaxis - This is the most common presentation. Patient may be markedly anemic due to repeated blood loss.
  • Progressive nasal obstruction and denasal speech i.e. Rhinolalia clausa - It is due to mass in the postnasal space.
  • Conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion- It occurs due to obstruction of eustachian tube.
  • Frog face deformity - broadening of nasal bridge along with proptosis and swelling in the cheek.

questions.text: Sexual asphyxia is seen in
questions.solution:
Sexual asphyxia is seen in masochism.

In masochism, the person obtains sexual gratification by suffering pain. Partial hanging can be used as a means to obtain sexual gratification. Failure to release the ligature might lead to asphyxia and death. This is known as sexual asphyxia(autoerotic death). It is more common in males.

Other options - 

Option A: Fetichism means the use of fetish for sexual gratification. A fetish is an abnormal stimulus or object of sexual desire. In this, recurrent, intense sexual fantasies, sexual urges or behaviour involving the use of living or non-living objects. It is almost exclusively seen in males. It is harmless, but rarely it may drive the person to obtain his fetish object through violence or criminal act.

Option C: Sexual oralism is obtaining sexual pleasure from the application of mouth to the sexual organs.

Option D: Necrophagia means sadistic perversion seen among male, who gets sexual gratification by tearing out the genitals or other parts like breasts, buttocks, etc. of their partner after her death by his teeth and may virtually eat them raw.

questions.text:
A patient who has motor paralysis had his CSF tested. It shows albuminocytologic dissociation. What is this finding characteristic of?

CSF - cerebrospinal fluid
questions.solution:
A patient with motor paralysis showing elevated CSF protein levels without pleocytosis (otherwise known as albuminocytological dissociation) is characteristic of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS).

GBS is an autoimmune disease that usually occurs following antecedent respiratory or gastrointestinal infection and manifests as ascending motor paralysis with or without sensory disturbance. The patient may complain of rubbery legs and the weakness develops within hours to a few days. 

The lower limb is affected more commonly. Deep tendon reflexes reduce or disappear. Lower cranial nerves are also frequently affected, causing difficulty in maintaining the airway. Autonomic involvement can cause fluctuations in blood pressure and cardiac arrhythmias.

There are many types of Guillain–Barre syndrome:

  • Demyelinating
    • Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP)- most common type
  • Axonal
    • Acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN)
    • Acute motor-sensory axonal neuropathy (AMSAN)
  • Regional GBS syndromes: Miller–Fisher syndrome (MFS)

Diagnosis is made upon clinical presentation. CSF findings of elevated protein without pleocytosis help to rule out other similar conditions. Treatment includes initiating intravenous immunoglobulins (IVIg) or plasmapheresis. IVIg is the initial therapy preferred, as it has a better safety record. In severe cases, patients may require ventilatory support.  

Other options :

Option A: Pseudotumor cerebri is also known as idiopathic intracranial hypertension. CSF is normal but there is an elevated opening pressure. It causes persistent headaches and papilledema. 

Option B: Multiple sclerosis is characterized by chronic inflammation and demyelination that causes multiple neurological symptoms such as optic neuritis, muscle spasticity, and facial weakness. The presence of oligoclonal bands on protein electrophoresis is diagnostic. 

Option D: The most common cause of subarachnoid hemorrhage, other than trauma, is a saccular aneurysm. CSF can be bloody or xanthochromic (yellow-stained) due to the production of bilirubin from lysed hemoglobin.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of Immunopathogenesis of Guillain-Barre Syndrome

The following sequence of events, takes into consideration, the development of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) associated with Campylobacter jejuni infection.

  1. B cells recognize glycoconjugates on jejuni (Cj) that cross-react with ganglioside present on Schwann cell surface and subjacent peripheral nerve myelin.
  2. Most of the B cells are activated via a partially T cell–dependent route and secrete primarily IgG autoantibodies. Some B cells, activated via a T cell–independent mechanism, secrete primarily IgM
  3. The activated B cells escape from Peyer’s patches into regional lymph nodes.
  4. Activated T cells also function to assist in the opening of the blood-nerve barrier, facilitating penetration of pathogenic autoantibodies.
  5. The earliest changes in myelin consist of edema between myelin lamellae and vesicular disruption of the outermost myelin layers.
  6. These effects are associated with activation of the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex and mediated by calcium entry; it is possible that the macrophage cytokine tumor necrosis factor (TNF) also participates in myelin damage.

Related Pearl: Antibodies seen in Guillian Barre syndrome

Type Antibody
AIDP Anti GM1
AMAN Anti GD1a
AMSAN Anti GD1a
Miller Fisher syndrome Anti GQ1b
  • AIDP-Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy 
  • AMAN-Acute motor axonal neuropathy 
  • AMSAN-Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy

questions.text: In Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) all of the following are true except?

choices.text: Type 2 occurs 5 to 14 days after therapy begins
Direct platelet-aggregating effect of heparin is seen in type 1
Type 2 is caused by antibodies that recognise complexes of heparin and platelet factor 5

questions.solution:
Type 2 of HIT is caused by antibodies that recognize complexes of heparin and platelet factor 4

Thrombocytopenia occurs in about 5% of persons receiving heparin and is of two types:

  • Type I thrombocytopenia
    • Occurs rapidly after the onset of therapy.
    • It most likely results from a direct platelet-aggregating effect of heparin.
    • Resolves spontaneously
  • Type II thrombocytopenia is
    • Less common.
    • It occurs 5 to 14 days after therapy begins.
    • It often leads to life-threatening venous and arterial thrombosis.
    • It is caused by antibodies that recognize complexes of heparin and platelet factor 4, which is a normal component of platelet granules.
    • Heparin should be discontinued and replaced with other non-heparin anticoagulants.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male diagnosed with parkinsonism and on treatment presented with the finding as seen in the image below.  Which of the following drugs is most likely implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows livedo reticularis and it is a side effect of amantadine.

Amantadine:

Amantadine inhibits the NMDA receptors(glutaminergic receptors) thereby mediating an anti-dyskinetic effect. It also blocks presynaptic dopamine reuptake, facilitates dopamine release, postsynaptic dopamine agonism, and/or dopamine receptor modulation. It also has an anti-viral effect by interfering with the function of the M2 protein and inhibiting viral replication.

 It is used in the treatment of influenza. Amantadine can be used in milder cases of parkinsonism or as a supplement to levodopa for advanced cases. It is also used in the management of levodopa-induced dyskinesia.

Adverse effects include restlessness, depression, irritability, insomnia, agitation, excitement, hallucinations, confusion, headache, heart failure, postural hypotension, urinary retention, and gastrointestinal disturbances like anorexia, nausea, constipation, and dry mouth. Livedo reticularis and peripheral edema can be seen in some cases.

Other options:

Option A: Apomorphine is a dopamine receptor agonist used in 'off' episodes of levodopa therapy.

Option B: Entacapone is a catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) inhibitor that decreases levodopa metabolism and prolongs its action.

Option D: Selegiline is an irreversible monoamine oxidase-B (MAO) inhibitor.

questions.text: All of the following conditions can cause a pathological fracture, except:
questions.solution:
Fabry's disease does not cause pathological fractures. It presents with angiokeratomas and acroparasthesias. 

Pathological fractures are fractures that occur in a weakened bone that has structurally changed due to some condition. They occur either spontaneously or due to minor trauma.

In Gaucher's disease, there is a deficiency of glucocerebrosidase. This leads to an accumulation of lipid-laden macrophages in the bone tissue, weakening the bone and causing fractures.

Osteogenesis imperfecta is an autosomal dominant disorder that occurs most commonly due to mutation in the COL1A and COL2A genes. This results in the abnormal formation of type 1 collagen. Since type 1 collagen is mainly present in the bone, the patient presents with repeated fractures with no or minimal trauma.

Hyperparathyroidism can cause severe bone resorption leading to bone pains and pathological fracture.

Overall, osteoporosis is the most common reason for pathological fractures. Below the age of 20, the common causes of pathological fracture are benign bone tumors and cysts.

Related Pearl: Pathological fracture

Pathological fractures occur with normal stresses in the bones that have been weakened by a change in its structure or through a lytic lesion.

Factors suggestive of a pathologic fracture:

  • Fracture after minor trauma
  • Pain at the site before the fracture
  • Multiple recent fractures
  • History of primary malignancy

Causes:

1. Generalized bone disease: 

  • Osteoporosis
  • Metabolic bone diseases
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Paget's disease
  • Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia
  • Myelomatosis

2. Local benign conditions:

  • Chronic infection
  • Solitary bone cyst
  • Aneurysmal bone cyst
  • Chondroma

3. Primary malignant tumors:

  • Chondrosarcoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Ewing's tumor

4. Metastatic tumors

  • Mets from breast, lung, kidney, thyroid, colon and prostate

questions.text: Which of the following is known as complex V of the ETC?
questions.solution:
ATP synthase is a multi-subunit enzyme complex, also referred to as complex V of the ETC. It synthesizes ATP by utilizing the energy of the proton gradient that is generated by the ETC.

It contains two domains:

  • Domain (Fo): spans the inner mitochondrial membrane
  • Domain (F1): extra membranous, which also protrudes into the mitochondrial matrix

The chemiosmotic theory states that the two processes (respiratory chain and synthesis of ATP) are coupled by a proton gradient across the inner mitochondrial membrane. The proton motive force caused by the electrochemical potential difference drives the mechanism of ATP synthesis.

questions.text: A child is below 3rd percentile for height. His growth velocity is normal, and chronological age is more than skeletal age. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
This boy with small stature and a normal growth velocity, as well as a chronological age that exceeds the skeletal age is coherent with a constitutional delay in growth.

Constitutional delay is the most common cause of delayed growth in children. The ultimate height attained is normal as well as children do have a normal growth velocity. Patients with constitutional delay have Bone age < Chronological age. It is also important to note that IGF -1 levels remain low for chronological age.

In summary there are 2 types of normal variants of short stature are :

Constitutional delay: – Bone age < Chronological age

Familial short stature: – Bone age = Chronological age (Option A)

Short stature can be defined as growth below the expected genetic potential or below -2 SD for age and sex. If a child's stature is less than -3 SD below the average for their age and gender it is more likely to indicate pathological short stature. A child's height between -2 and -3 SD is more likely due to physiological, i.e. familial or constitutional short stature.

Given below is a graphical representation showing the various patterns of the causes of short stature.

Other options:

Option B: Seckel Syndrome, Silver-Russell Syndrome, Microcephalic Osteodysplastic Primordial Dwarfism types I/III, II, and Meier-Gorlin Syndrome are all classified as primordial dwarfism. Due to the disorganized molecular and genomic alterations that occur during the embryonic stage, this group of genetic disorders is distinguished by postnatal growth abnormalities and intrauterine growth retardation. 

Option D: Patients with hypopituitarism have a growth curve that initially follows the average pattern but then deviates below the mean curve and gradually tapers off. This represents postnatal onset pathologic short stature.

Bone age Less than chronological age Normal  
Puberty Delayed Normal

questions.text: Windkessel effect is seen in:
questions.solution:
The windkessel effect is seen in the large elastic arteries like the aorta.

The elasticity or windkessel effect is the exclusive property of large and elastic vessels like the aorta. These vessels when stretched undergo elastic recoil.

Aorta is stretched during systole, this expansion causes temporary storage of blood so that more blood enters the aorta. This buffer stock of blood is released during diastole, to maintain organ perfusion even during diastole. 

The image given below shows the windkessel effect seen in the aorta.

Proteins responsible for aortic elasticity are elastin and fibrillin. If elastin undergoes mutation it results in supravalvular aortic stenosis as seen in William's syndrome. If fibrillin undergoes mutation it results in dilatation of the aortic root due to cystic medial necrosis as seen in Marfan syndrome.

Aorta has the highest blood flow velocity. Blood flow velocity is inversely proportional to the cross-sectional area of the blood vessel. Therefore, the aorta has the lowest cross-sectional area.

Related Pearl: Types of Blood Vessels

Types of Blood Vessels

TYPES

FEATURES

Windkessel vessels

Aorta and large arteries.

Abundant elastic tissues in the inner and external elastic lamina

Shows elastic recoil (windkessel effect) when stretched

Resistance vessels

Arterioles

Have less elastic tissue and lot of smooth muscle (maximum wall thickness to lumen ratio)

Major site of resistance to blood flow

Exchange vessels

Capillaries

Do not have smooth muscles, consist of single layer of endothelial cells surrounded by a basement membrane

Site of exchange of nutrients, water and gases

Types

  • Continuous- brain, retina (have tight junctions)
  • Fenestrated- glomeruli, choroid plexus
  • Sinusoidal- liver, spleen

Blood flow regulation is by contraction and relaxation of the arterioles and precapillary sphincter

Capacitance vessels

Venules & veins

Thin-walled, easily distensible (maximum percentage of blood volume)

Shunt vessels

AV anastomoses

Have thick muscular walls with rich innervation

Found in – finger tips, ear lobes

questions.text: In which of the given conditions is spina ventosa seen?
questions.solution:
Spina ventosa is a feature of tuberculous dactylitis. This refers to the tuberculosis of short tubular bones i.e. metacarpals, metatarsals, and phalanges.

The infection is lodged in the marrow cavity leading to spindle-shaped expansion/ ballooned-out appearance of the bone known as spina ventosa. Periosteal reaction, abscess, and sinus formation are seen.

TB sicca or caries sicca is the tuberculosis of the shoulder joint. It usually does not have any effusion of joint, hence it is known as sicca which is a Latin word for 'dry'.

The image below shows tuberculous dactylitis. Note the swelling in the affected phalanx.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a physiological uncoupler?
questions.solution:
Thermogenin is a physiological uncoupler.

Uncouplers mediate their effects by increasing the permeability of the mitochondrial membrane to ions, thereby leading to a collapse in the proton gradient established by allowing the H+ to pass across the membrane without going through the ATP synthase enzyme complex.

Examples:

  • Synthetic: 2, 4 dinitrophenol
  • Natural: Thermogenin which is found naturally in the brown adipose tissue, whose function is heat generation, especially in a newborn, and thyroxine

questions.text: A cohort study was conducted in 10,000 smokers and they were followed up over a period of 10 years. It was found that 100 people developed lung carcinoma. 10,000 people from the general population were also studied and only 10 of them developed lung cancer. Calculate the relative risk:
questions.solution:
In this scenario

                           Disease
Exposure   yes no
yes 100 (a) 9900 (b)
no 10  (c) 9990 (d)

Relative risk calculatin (RR) = [a/(a+b)]/ [c/(c+d)].

Thus making RR = 10.

Relative Risk

      • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
      • It is also called risk ratio.
      • It is the direct measure of strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
      • RR = 1 indicates no association.
      • RR of 2 or higher indicates a 100% increase in risk.

questions.text: Obstetric conjugate is
questions.solution:
Obstetric conjugate is one of the anteroposterior diameters of the pelvic inlet and it measures 10 cm.

Anteroposterior diameters of the pelvic inlet:

  • Anatomical/true conjugate/conjugate vera:
    • It is the distance between the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the inner margin of the upper border of symphysis pubis. 
    • It measures 11 cm.
  • Obstetric conjugate:
    • It is the distance between the midpoint of the sacral promontory to prominent bony projection in the midline on the inner surface of the symphysis pubis.
    • It measures 10 cm (4")
  • Diagonal conjugate:
    • It is the distance between the lower border of symphysis pubis to the midpoint on the sacral promontory. 
    • It measures 12 cm (4 ¾")

Clinically diagonal conjugate is measured and obstetric conjugate is derived by subtracting 1.5 - 2cm from the diagonal conjugate.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with chronic heart failure presents with a particular breathing pattern. His depth and rate of respiration are plotted as given below. The type of breathing abnormality seen here is?
questions.solution:
The type of breathing abnormality shown in the image is suggestive of Cheyne-Stokes breathing. 

Cheyne-Stokes breathing is characterized by periods of waxing and waning hyperventilation separated by periods of apnea, as seen in the image. This pattern is seen at high altitudes and in patients with severe heart disease or brain injury.

 
In Cheyne-Stokes respiration, the person ventilates excessively, leading to an excessive loss of CO2 and an increased concentration of O2 in the blood. These changes in the blood are detected only after a few seconds after the pulmonary blood reaches the brain. Thus ventilation does not get inhibited immediately.
 
When the overventilated blood finally reaches the respiratory center in the brain, the center gets excessively depressed, and ventilation is inhibited. This leads to increased CO2 and decreased O2 in the alveoli. It takes the center a few more seconds to respond to these reversed changes, leading to excessive ventilation. The cycle then repeats.
 
 
In severe chronic cardiac failure, blood flow from the lungs to the brain is slow. This leads to alveolar changes in the CO2 and O2 occurring for longer than usual and excessive storage of these gases within the alveoli and pulmonary blood. After a few seconds, the periodic respiratory drive becomes extreme and Cheyne-Stokes breathing begins. 
 
Other options:
Option A: Kussmaul's breathing is a form of hyperventilation. It occurs due to an increased tidal volume with or without an increase in respiratory rate. It is seen in association with any condition that leads to acidosis.
 
Option B: Biot's breathing is characterized by regular deep respirations with periods of apnea. It occurs due to pontine damage by stroke, trauma, or uncal herniation. 
 
Option D: Hyperpnea refers to an increased volume of respiration with or without an increased rate of breathing. Blood gas concentrations are normal.
 
The different patterns of respiration are shown below.

questions.text: Guerin’s fracture is:

questions.text: The finding of the immunohistochemistry studies of a patient with a neurodegenerative disease is given below. Identify the structure marked in the image.
questions.solution:
The given image is the histological sample of the substantia nigra showing neurons with a Lewy body, extracellular neuromelanin, and pigment-laden macrophages n Parkinson's disease. 

Lewy bodies are single or multiple intracytoplasmic, round to elongated, eosinophilic inclusions that often have a dense core surrounded by a pale halo. Accumulations of these are seen in subcortical regions (basal ganglia, striatum, locus coeruleus, substantia nigra, thalamus) as well as the cerebral cortex. Lewy bodies are aggregates of insoluble fibrillar proteins called alpha-synuclein (specific) and ubiquitin in the neural cells. They are typically seen in Parkinson's disease, Lewy body dementia, and a few variants of Alzheimer's disease. They mainly disrupt the excitatory dopaminergic pathways.

 Other options:

Pick bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, weakly basophilic filamentous inclusions that stain strongly with silver methods. It contains 3R tau and is seen in frontotemporal lobar degeneration.

 

Negri bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions found in pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. They are pathognomonic microscopic findings seen in rabies.

 

Lafora bodies are seen in the cytoplasm of neurons in myoclonic epilepsy. Lafora bodies are aggregates of polyglucosans, poorly constructed glycogen molecules with inordinately long strands that render them insoluble.

questions.text: The below given image depicts:
questions.solution:

Technique: Malar flexion and shoulder traction

  • Baby placed on supinated left forearm with arms hanging by the side.
  • Middle and index finger of left hand placed over baby’s malar bones to maintain flexion of head.

Technique:

  • Baby is swung in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

Option C: Lovset’smaneuver – Used for delivery of extended arms in case of breech presentation.

Option D: Pinard’smaneuver used for delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Catch hold the ankle
  • Pull down by movement of abduction

questions.text: Which of the following interleukin causes isotype switching to IgE:
questions.solution:
TH2 cells produce a number of cytokines upon encounter with the antigen; the important among these are IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13.

IL-4 acts on B cells to stimulate class switching to IgE and promotes the development of additional TH2 cells.

IL-5 is involved in the development and activation of eosinophils, which are important effectors of type I hypersensitivity
(discussed later).

IL-13 enhances IgE production and acts on epithelial cells to stimulate mucus secretion. In addition, TH2 cells (as well as mast cells and epithelial cells) produce chemokines that attract more TH2 cells, as well as other leukocytes, to the reaction site.

questions.text: A young female patient with a recent travel history comes to the OPD with a history of prolonged abdominal pain, diarrhea, and fever gradually increasing in a step ladder pattern. On examination, faint, salmon-colored macules are seen on the trunk. A serological test is used to confirm the diagnosis. This test is an example of
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of enteric fever/ typhoid fever. Widal test is an agglutination test done in case of typhoid fever.

Typhoid fever is caused by Salmonella typhi. The clinical course may vary from mild undifferentiated pyrexia to a rapidly fatal disease. Clinical manifestations include malaise, step ladder pyrexia, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and myalgia. Hepatosplenomegaly is a common finding on examination. Rose spots are small erythematous maculopapular lesions that are seen on the chest and abdomen that fade on pressure. They appear in the second week and are seen as shown below

Widal test:

It is a type of tube agglutination test in which, H and O agglutinins for typhoid and paratyphoid bacilli are measured in the serum sample. It is performed by mixing equal volumes (0.4 ml) of serial dilutions of the serum (from 1/10 to 1/640) with fixed volumes of H and O antigens in the Dreyer's and Felix agglutination tubes, respectively. These tubes are incubated overnight and the agglutination titres are read. H agglutination leads to the formation of cotton woolly clumps while O agglutination is seen as a disc-like pattern at the bottom of the tube.

Interpretation of Widal test: 

  • Demonstration of a rise in titre of antibodies by testing two or more serum samples is more meaningful than a single test.
  • H agglutinin titer > 1/640 and O agglutinin titer >1/320 is considered significant.

Other options

  • Option b: In tube flocculation test, serial dilutions of the toxin/ toxoid are added to tubes containing a fixed quantity of antitoxin. The amount of toxin or toxoid that flocculates optimally with one unit of the antitoxin is defined as Lf dose. Example: Kahn test for syphilis.
  • Option c: In slide flocculation test, a drop each of the antigen and antiserum are placed on the slide and mixed by shaking; appearance of floccules is taken as positive. Eg. VDRL test for syphilis
  • Option d: In Ring precipitation test, antigen solution is layered over a column of antiserum in a narrow tube. the precipitate is formed at the junction of the 2 liquids. Example: Ascoli’s thermoprecipitin test for detection of anthrax antigen.

Tube flocculation, slide flocculation and ring precipitation test are all types of precipitation tests.

questions.text: Russel bodies are accumulations of:
questions.solution:
Russel bodies are intracellular cytoplasmic accumulations of immunoglobulins seen in plasmacytoma.

Similar accumulation is called a Dutcher Body if nuclear

Protein accumulations are less common than lipid accumulations.  Some examples of protein accumulations include

  • In kidney trace amounts of albumin are reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubules. But in Nephrotic syndrome there is heavy protein loss through the glomerular filter. Large amount of protein is reabsorbed and the vesicles accumulating these proteins give the histologic appearance of pink, hyaline cytoplasmic droplets.
  • In myeloma, large amounts of immunoglobulins are produced by the abnormal plasma cells. The ER becomes hugely distended, producing large, homogeneous eosinophilic inclusions called Russell bodies.
  • Neurofibrillary tangles in the neurons in Alzheimer’s disease.
  • Alcoholic hyaline in the liver.

questions.text: Which of the following will be seen in a patient with Marion’s disease?

choices.text: Hypertrophy of the internal sphincter of the bladder
Hypertrophy of the external sphincter of the bladder
Congenital obstruction of the prostatic urethra

questions.solution:
Hypertrophy of the internal sphincter of the bladder is seen in Marion’s disease. This leads to bladder outlet obstruction. Its clinical features include voiding and storage symptoms (usually associated with BPH). Therefore it is also called prostatism sans prostate:

  • Increased urinary frequency
  • Urgency
  • Dribbling of urine
  • Hesitancy
  • Intermittent stream
  • Nocturia

It is commonly seen in young patients.

Bladder outlet obstruction can occur due to 2 causes:

  • Muscular causes
    • Congenital hypertrophy of internal sphincter, i.e., Marion's disease
    • Dyssynergic contraction of the smooth muscle of the bladder neck (bladder neck dyssynergia)
  • Fibrosis of bladder neck following transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP)

questions.text: Classification used to assess the severity of abruptio placenta is:
questions.solution:
Page classification is used to assess the severity of abruption placenta.

PAGE classification:

  • Grade 0 – Asymptomatic, abruption is diagnosed only after delivery by the presence of retroplacental clots.
  • Grade 1 – Vaginal bleeding, mild uterine tetani. No maternal and fetal complications.
  • Grade 2 – With fetal distress or death
  • Grade 3 – With maternal complications like shock, renal failure, coagulopathy or death.

Option B: FJ Browne classification is used for placenta previa.

Option C: Priscilla White’s classification was originally used to assess the perinatal outcome and toformulate the obstetric management. But it is now mainly used for statistical correlation of different types of pregnant diabetes.

Clinical features

- Inattentive symptoms: Difficulty focusing, distractible, does not listen or follow instructions, disorganised, forgetful, loses/misplaces objects.

- Hyperactive/impulsive symptoms: Fidgety, unable to sit still, “driven by a motor”, hyper-talkative, interrupts, blurts out answers.

  • Non-stimulants: Atomoxetine(nor epinephrine reuptake inhibitor), alpha-2 adrenergic agonists
  • Behavioural therapy

questions.text: A term neonate born by vacuum-assisted delivery developed mild respiratory distress 1 hour after birth. Arterial oxygen saturation remained > 95% without supplemental oxygen. Chest radiography performed 6 hours after birth is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and radiograph showing a spinnaker sign is suggestive of pneumomediastinum.

Spinnaker sign (also called angel wing sign) is a radiographic sign seen in neonates with pneumomediastinum. Pneumomediastinum is the presence of extraluminal gas within the mediastinum. The pressure from the collected gas displaces the two lobes of the thymic tissue upward and laterally from its normal position. This results in large, wedge-shaped opacities on radiograph resembling the spinnaker headsails of a boat.

This should be distinguished from a thymic sail sign which is a normal finding on a neonatal chest x-ray. It represents a physiologically enlarged thymus in a neonate.

Other signs of pneumomediastinum are:

  • V sign of Naclerio - It is due to a V-shaped air collection. One limb of the V is produced by mediastinal air outlining the left lower lateral mediastinal border and the other limb is produced by air between the parietal pleura and medial left hemidiaphragm.
  • Continuous diaphragm sign - Normally the central portion of the diaphragm is not discretely visualised on chest radiographs as it merges with the cardiac silhouette. If the diaphragm can be seen continuously across the midline then it is suggestive of free gas within the mediastinum.

The image given below shows the V sign of Naclerio.

The image given below shows continuous diaphragm sign.

questions.text: Suspected cause preceding the observed effect is an example of:
questions.solution:
In Hill’s criteria of causal association, temporality is where the suspected cause precedes the observed effect.

Related Pearl: Hill's Criteria for Causal Association

  • It is also called Bradford Hill criteria.
  • It was established in 1965 by English epidemiologist, Sir Austin Bradford Hill.

Criteria

Brief Description

Temporality

Suspected cause precedes observed effect.

Strength

Larger the relative risk, the more likely it is causal.

Consistency

If the association is observed repeatedly under the same or various conditions, then more likely it is causation.

Specificity

When exposure is associated with a specific outcome only, then it is more likely to be causal.

Plausibility

A biologically plausible mechanism between cause and effect can be support for causation.

Coherence

A causal conclusion should not seriously conflict with the present substantive knowledge of the outcome.

Analogy

Other established cause-effect relationships may be used in analogies to support this causal relationship.

Gradient

It is called dose-response or response curve. It refers to the existence of an exposure-response relationship.

Experiment

To check if the condition can be or has been changed, weakened or prevented by experimental approach.

questions.text: False statement about anorexia nervosa is:

choices.text: Loss of weight according to patient

questions.solution:
• Anorexia nervosa patients are secretive about their symptoms and deny any weight loss or any other symptoms.
  • Anorexia is most commonly seen in adolescent females.
  • Appetite of these patients is usually normal.

Clinical features include:

Distortion of body image (patient perceives that she is fat despite being thin in reality)

  • Excessive fear of gaining weight
  • BMI <18.5
  • Patients exhibit peculiar behaviour which includes hiding food in the house, trying to dispose food in napkins.
  • There is poor sexual development in adolescent females.
  • Symptoms secondary to weight loss include amenorrhoea, lanugo (appearance of neonatal hairs), hypothermia, dependent edema.

Anorexia can be classified into two types:

Restrictive type: where the food intake grossly reduced.

Binge eating/purging type: alternative episodes of rigorous dieting with intermittent binging and purging episodes (self-induced vomiting, laxative, diuretic use. These patients may have dental caries, parotitis, and hypokalaemic alkalosis due to repeated vomiting.

 Treatment:

  • Cognitive Behavioural therapy
  • Nutritional rehabilitation
  • Olanzapine if not responding to CBT and nutritional rehabilitation
                                                      Eating Disorders
Diagnosis Clinical Features Treatment
Anorexia nervosa
  • BMI <18.5
  • Intense fear of weight gain
  • Distorted views on body weight and shape
  • Cognitive-behavioural therapy
  • Nutritional rehabilitation
  • Olanzapine if no response to above
Bulimia nervosa
  • Recurrent episodes of binge eating
  • Binge eating followed by compensatory behaviour to prevent weight gain
  • Excess worriying about body shape and weight
  • Maintains normal body weight (BMI 18.5-30)
  • Cognitive-behavioural therapy
  • Nutritional rehabilition 
  • SSRI (fluxetine), often in combination to above
Binge- eating disorder
  • Recurrent episodes of binge-eating
  • No compensatory behaviours
  • Lack of control during eating
  • Cognitive-behavioural therapy
  • Behavioural weight loss therapy
  • SSRI
  • Lisderxamfetamine, topiramate

questions.text: A first-time mother rushes to the OPD with her 4-day old infant and worriedly points to the rash that appears as shown below. You reassure her of its harmless, transient nature.  On microscopic examination, these papular lesions on an erythematous base will reveal ________
questions.solution:
The given clinical complex describes a case of erythema neonatorum. Wright stained smear of the contents of the pustule will show an abundance of eosinophils.

They are papular lesions on an erythematous base, distributed over the trunk and face predominantly. They are seen 1-3 days after birth and may persist for up to a week, after which they resolve spontaneously.

Neutrophils are seen in pustular melanosis. 

 

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: Most abundant cytosolic protein:
questions.solution:
Collagen is most abundant protein but it is extracellular.

  • Most abundant overall and extracellular protein – Collagen
  • Most abundant intracellular protein – Actin

Actin:

  • Actin microfilaments are 5- to 9-nm diameter fibrils formed from the globular protein actin (G-actin), the most abundant cytosolic protein in cells.
  • The G-actin monomers noncovalently polymerize into long filaments (F-actin) that intertwine to form double-stranded helices with a defined polarity; new globular subunits are added (or lost) at the “positive” end of the strand.
  • In muscle cells, the filamentous protein myosin binds to actin, and moves along it, driven by ATP hydrolysis (the basis of muscle contraction).
  • In non-muscle cells, F-actin assembles via an assortment of actin-binding proteins into well-organized bundles and networks that control cell shape and movement.

questions.text: Salivation of dog when food is given along with bell is:
questions.solution:
Salivation of dog when food is given (along with bell or without bell) is an example of innate reflex.

Option C :

  • For a conditioned reflex to occur, the bell should ring before the food is kept in the dog’s mouth.
  • This should be repeated a number of times.
  • Until when the dog would salivate on ringing of the bell in spite of no food being kept.

questions.text: A forensic expert is assisting the police in investigating the death of a woman. On examination, he notices the Kevorkian sign. What is the estimated time since the death?
questions.solution:
The Kevorkian sign is a postmortem change that occurs in the retinal vessels. It lasts for about 1 hour.

It is characterized by fragmentation of the blood column in the retinal vessels. It appears within minutes after death and lasts for about 1 hour. It can be visualized by using an ophthalmoscope as shown below.

Other postmortem changes occurring in the eye:

  • Cornea - dull, hazy, opaque, wrinkled
  • Flaccidity of eyeballs occurs due to falling in intraocular pressure. IOP reaches zero at the end of 2 hours after death
  • Tache Noir: A film of cell debris and mucus forms two yellow triangles on the sclera on either side of the cornea, with base towards the margin of cornea and apex towards medial or lateral canthus of the eye. It appears within 3-4 hours of death
  • Increase in potassium concentration in vitreous - linear increase up to 100 hours following death. It is helpful in determining the time since death

questions.text: Which of the following findings in a healthy term child would warrant further evaluation?
questions.solution:
Buphthalmos is not a normal finding in a newborn; it is suggestive of congenital glaucoma and should, therefore, be investigated.

The sclera and cornea are more elastic in early childhood and an increase in intraocular pressure (IOP), therefore, leads to an expansion of the globe and the development of buphthalmos (“ox eye”).

Recommended screening for eye diseases at birth:

  • Buphthalmos
  • Cataract
  • Ophthalmia Neonatorum
  • Developmental anomalies - Microphthalmos, Anophthalmos
  • Nystagmus
  • Squint
  • Retinopathy of prematurity

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding babies with intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR) ?

choices.text: Increased  head circumference / Abdominal circumference (HC/AC) ratio
Increased diastolic velocity in middle cerebral artery (MCA) doppler
Femur length/ Abdominal circumference (FL/AC) ratio is >23.5

questions.solution:
• Ponderal Index (PI) is a weight-height related parameter that is mainly used to assess the pattern of fetal growth.
  • It is calculated by multiplying the weight in grams by 100 and then dividing by cube of length in cm.
  • This parameter is usually < 2 in Asymmetric IUGR and 2 or more in babies with normal growth or having Symmetric IUGR ( Not > 10th percentile).

Other options:

  • Increased head circumference (HC) to abdominal circumference (AC) ratio (seen in asymmetrical IUGR type).
  • Fetal middle cerebral artery (MCA) systolic/diastolic (S/D) ratio is an important parameter in fetal middle cerebral arterial Doppler assessment . A reduced S/D ratio is abnormal and implies an increased diastolic flow in MCA which is a useful predictor of fetal distress and intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR).
  • Femur length/ Abdominal circumference (FL/AC) ratio is >23.5 suggests IUGR as FL/AC ratio is 22 at all gestational ages from 21 weeks to term.

  • Type II -
