questions.text: A child from an urban slum area is admitted to your unit and is receiving treatment for Kwashiorkor. Which of the following is not true regarding the treatment?

choices.text: Suspect primary treatment failure if appetite is not regained by day 4
Suspect secondary treatment failure if oedema reappears after 4 weeks

questions.solution:
In a child with kwashiorkor, iron therapy (3 mg/kg/day) should be started only once the child starts gaining weight. Iron should not be given in the stabilization phase because excess iron can lead to free radical formation.

The image below explains the treatment protocol to be followed in the case of PEM.

The following should strike a suspicion of treatment failure in PEM:

Inpatient cases:

Primary Failure Secondary failure

Failure to regain appetite by day 4.

Failure to start losing oedema by day 4.

Presence of oedema on day 10.

Failure to gain at least 5 g/kg/day by day 10.

Failure to gain 5 g/kg/day for 3 consecutive days during rehabilitation.

Reappearance of oedema after 4 weeks.

Outpatient cases:

Primary failure Secondary failure

Failure to gain any weight by 2 weeks

Failure to lose oedema in 4 weeks

No weight gain in two visits

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented with personality changes, abnormal movements, jaundice and pruritus. MRI of the brain was taken and is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image given is an axial FLAIR MRI of a patient with Wilson’s disease having the face of the giant panda appearance.

Wilson’s disease is a rare, autosomal recessive disorder characterized by excessive deposition of free copper in tissues. It is due to a loss of function mutation of the ATP7B gene. It is also known as hepatolenticular degenerative disease.

MRI brain in advanced disease with neurological manifestations can show the following:

  • Giant panda face sign: Hypointense superior colliculus (chin and mouth of panda), the hyperintense area around the tegmentum of the midbrain (eyes of panda), and normal substantia nigra (ears of panda).
  • Bright claustrum sign: Thin rim of a hyperintense area in the claustrum with normal putamen.
  • Mercedes-Benz/trident sign: Hyperintense pons trisected by a hypointense line.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child from a rural slum area is brought to your OPD with deformity as shown in the image. Which of the following conditions is characteristically associated with this deformity?

Other deformities of extremities seen in rickets:

  • Valgus or varus deformities of limbs
  • Anterior bowing of the tibia and femur
  • Coxa vara

questions.text: A patient presents with persistent iron deficiency anemia and GI endoscopy reveals the dilated venules as shown in the below image. what is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image of endoscopy shows dilated venules appearing as linear red streaks converging on the antrum in longitudinal fashion, giving ‘Watermelon appearance of stomach’ which is characteristic of Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia.

questions.text: Nysten’s rule describes the sequential onset of:
questions.solution:
Nysten’s rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis.

Rigor mortis is also known as cadaveric rigidity or death stiffening. It refers to the stiffening and shortening of muscles following death. Both voluntary and involuntary muscles are involved. In India, it begins 1-2 hours following death.

Nysten's rule describes the order of appearance of rigor mortis in the various muscle groups. It first appears in the myocardium, which becomes rigid in an hour. The order of appearance of rigor mortis is:

Myocardium> eyelids > neck and lower jaw > face> muscles of chest > upper limb> abdomen > lower limb > fingers and toes (proximo-distal progression)

It passes off in the same order of its appearance.

Medicolegal importance:

  • Sign of death
  • Helps in estimating the time of death, but is not reliable
  • Indicates the position of the body at the time of death

Conditions that simulate rigor mortis include heat stiffening, cold stiffening, and cadaveric spasm.

questions.text: Onion skin fibrosis is seen in
questions.solution:
Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is associated with onion skin fibrosis around atrophic bile duct lumen.

  • PSC is characterized by inflammation and obliterative fibrosis of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts with dilation of preserved segments.
  • Characteristic “beading” on radiographs of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree is attributable to these irregular, biliary strictures and dilations.
  • Atypical perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (pANCA) targeting a nuclear envelope protein are found in approximately 65% of patients.
  • Smaller ducts, however, often have little inflammation and show a striking circumferential “onion skin” fibrosis around an increasingly atrophic duct lumen, eventually leading to obliteration by a “tombstone” scar.
  • The annual risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma is 0.6 to 1.5 % with a lifetime risk of 20%.

questions.text: Which of the following antiepileptic drug does not act via inhibition of sodium channels:

questions.text: The eldest child of a ragpicker from the urban slums of Bandra presents with severe lower limb pain. Examination reveals swelling of costochondral junctions. The X-ray image obtained is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?

  • Wimberger ring sign: Sclerotic rings around the epiphyses of the femur and tibia.

Late changes

  • Trummerfeld zone: Zones of destruction in the femur and tibia
  • Pelkan spur at the cortical end

The image sums up the X-ray features noted in scurvy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in Leprosy?
questions.solution:
Proprioception and vibration sense are not impaired in leprosy.

Other options:
Voluntary muscle wasting is seen in leprosy. Nerve involvement in leprosy causes motor palsy leading to an abnormal EMG.
Decreased sensations are classically seen in leprosy.
However, an increased tactile response is seen in Type I Lepra reaction with hyperesthesia.

Leprosy (Hansen’s disease) is a chronic infective granulomatous disease caused by the bacillus Mycobacterium leprae.

Leprosy is clinically characterized by one or more of the following features :

  • Hypopigmented patches
  • Partial or total loss of cutaneous sensation in the affected areas (the earliest sensation to be affected is usually light touch)
  • Presence of thickened nerves, and
  • Presence of acid-fast bacilli in the skin or nasal smears.
  • The earliest sign of leprosy is loss of temperature, usually over the hands and feet.
  • The onset of leprosy is insidious, with sensory changes often preceding skin lesions by several years.
  • Dysthesia develops in a progressive manner.
  • The ability to differentiate between hot and cold may be lost before the pinprick sensation- dissociated sensory loss  
  • The sensations are lost in the following order: Temperature > Fine Touch > Pain > Deep touch or pressure

questions.text: A child who used to play for hours together now comes back home and says he gets tired too easily, his concerned mother brings him to you. On auscultation, you find that there is a wide and fixed splitting of the second heart sound, ECG shows left axis deviation and features of left ventricular hypertrophy. What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Wide splitting of the 2nd heart sound with left axis deviation (LAD) and left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) points to the diagnosis of ostium primum atrial septal defect (ASD). Wide-fixed splitting of the 2nd heart sound is characteristic of ASD. 

In ostium primum ASD, the basic abnormality is the combination of left-to-right shunt across the atrial defect and mitral insufficiency due to mitral valve clefts. Mitral valvular insufficiency increases the volume load on the left ventricle (seen as LAD & LVH on ECG). When mitral insufficiency is severe enough to cause clinical symptoms like fatigue on exertion, the left atrium enlarges as a result of the regurgitant flow, and the left ventricle becomes hypertrophied and dilated.

questions.text: You are counseling a diabetic patient to consume foods with low glycemic index. Which of the following would you advise him to eat?
questions.solution:
The patient should be advised to eat whole grains since it has a low glycemic index (GI).

GI is a number representing the relative ability of a carbohydrate food to increase the level of glucose in the blood. It is calculated by comparing the test carbohydrate to the standard (glucose or white bread). This measure has practical use in the management of diabetes and obesity.

  • Low GI foods – most fruits and vegetables, whole grains, pasta foods, beans, and lentils.
  • Moderate GI foods – sucrose, basmati rice, and brown rice.
  • High GI foods – corn flakes, baked potatoes, white bread, potatoes, watermelon, candies, and syrupy foods.

questions.text: 25-year-old male feels moderately distressed while using the lift, being in crowded places and travelling alone. All of the following are recommended for treatment for his condition except:
questions.solution:
The symptoms of the patient in question are suggestive of agoraphobia. Benzodiazepines are not recommended by NICE guidelines to be prescribed for panic disorder with or without agoraphobia as they are associated with less good outcome in the long term. This is because, although benzodiazepines provide immediate relief, the panic symptoms return quickly if the drug is withdrawn. Also with the use of benzodiazepines, there is potential for dependence, cog­nitive impairment, and abuse, particularly with long-term use. 

Other options:

  • SSRIs: Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors should be used as the first line treatment modality for the management of panic attacks with or without agoraphobia. SSRIs with longer half-lives may be used to prevent discontinuation syndrome (increased anxiety, irritability, tearfulness, dizziness or lighthead­edness, malaise, sleep disturbance, and concentration difficulties). 
  • Cognitive and Behavioural Therapy (CBT): It is the prefered psychological modality of treatment for treatment of panic attack and agoraphobia. Combination of exposure therapy with relaxation training (as a CBT intervention) is found to be the most consistently efficacious approach to treatment. Studies suggest the effectiveness of CBT to be equal to pharmacotherapy and may also be used as a first line modality in suitable cases. However, combined treatment with CBT and SSRIs is believed to be superior to either CBT or SSRIs alone.
  • Self-help in the form of support groups and relaxation training should be offered and encouraged for mild and moderate panic disorder and agoraphobia.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: What is the most radiosensitive phase of the cell cycle?
questions.solution:
The cells are most radiosensitive in the G2-M phase of the cell cycle. 

This is because the cells lack sufficient time to repair DNA damage before division in the G2-M phase, leading to mitotic catastrophe. 

Radiosensitivity gradually decreases from G1 to the early S phase and is the least in the late S phase, where homologous recombination repair is most active after DNA replication.

questions.text: Dysthymia is:
questions.solution:
Dysthymia is defined as any mild depressionwhich is not severe enough to be called a depressiveepisode, and lasts for two years or more. It is more common in females.

Persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia)
DSM-5 criteria

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient with neurocysticercosis develops generalized peeling of skin (except palms and soles) and severe oral and genital involvement starting 1 month after taking seizure medication. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Generalized skin involvement (which indicates > 30%), severe oral and genital involvement are features of toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN).

TEN usually starts between 4 days to 4 weeks after initiation of drugs such as phenytoin, carbamazepine, lamotrigine. Palms and soles involvement is a feature that is classically seen in erythema multiforme and not in TEN (which has more truncal involvement).

SJS/TEN is primarily a drug‐induced phenomenon, with a culprit drug being demonstrated in approximately 85% of cases.

Common drugs that can cause SJS/TEN are:

  • Allopurinol
  • NSAIDs - oxicam group
  • Anti-epileptics - phenobarbital, phenytoin, carbamazepine, lamotrigine
  • Antibiotics - penicillins, cephalosporins, sulfamethoxazole, sulfasalazine, nevirapine

In 15% of the cases, where the drug cannot be identified, especially in children, appear to be triggered by infections, most notably by Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

Note: FDA recommends genotyping before starting carbamazepine, as HLA B1502 allele which is seen in increased frequencies among Asians is implicated in carbamazepine induced SJS/TEN.

SJS/TEN is classified based on severity and involvement of body surface area (BSA)

SJS Epidermal detachment of less than 10% BSA with widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets
SJS/TEN overlap Epidermal detachment of 10-30% BSA with widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets
TEN with spots Epidermal detachment of >30% BSA with widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets
TEN without spots Epidermal detachment of >30% BSA with loss of large epidermal sheets without widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets

Complications of SJS/TEN involve loss of thermoregulatory control, severe dehydration, and septicemia. Dehydration can cause acute kidney injury due to hypoperfusion. 

The first step in management is to identify and stop the offending drug. Those with extensive loss of epidermis should be admitted to the burns unit for skin-directed therapy, fluid replacement, and nutrition. The skin should be carefully handled to avoid further removal of skin. In addition, local therapy should be provided for the eyes, mouth, and urogenital tract. Patients should be given analgesia and be monitored for infection. Immunomodulating drugs like corticosteroids and cyclosporin may be used.

Other options :

Option A : Stevens-Johnson Syndrome (SJS) is a drug-induced condition characterized by widespread epithelial keratinocyte necrosis of both skin and mucous membranes. It is due to cytotoxic T-lymphocytes. But SJS has <10% involvement of skin and not a generalized involvement as seen in this patient.

Option B : Fixed drug eruptions present up to 8 hours of drug intake. These are erythematous lesions that heal with hyperpigmentation. Mucosal involvement is rare.

Option D - Pemphigus vulgaris is a chronic autoimmune blistering disease due to antibodies against desmosomal adhesion proteins. Patients usually present with oral lesions which are the predominant feature. There are flaccid blisters which rupture. The following image shows the multiple ruptured and flaccid blisters.

questions.text: Secretion of casein by mammary gland cells is an example of
questions.solution:
• Mammary gland cells secrete  milk protein, casein, by merocrine secretion.
  • Milk fat is secreted by apocrine secretion
  • In merocrine secretion, secretions are initially packaged into membrane-bound vesicles which then fuse with the plasma membrane to release their contents to the exterior. It is by far the most common secretory mechanism.
  • In apocrine glands, some of the apical cytoplasm is pinched off with the contained secretions, which are stored in the cell as membrane-free droplets.
  • In holocrine glands, cells first fill with secretory products, after which the entire cell disintegrates to liberate the accumulated mass of secretion into the adjacent duct.
  • Glands such as simple sweat glands of skin, where ions and water are actively transported from plasma as an exudate, were once classified as eccrine glands. They are now known to synthesize and secrete small amounts of protein by a merocrine mechanism, and have been reclassified as merocrine glands.
  • Type of Gland and location:
    Apocrine glands  Secretion of milk fat by mammary gland cells, specialized sweat glands in the axilla and anogenital regions of the body. 
    Merocrine glands  Secretion of milk protein, sweat glands previously classified as eccrine glands 
    Holocrine glands  sebaceous glands in the skin

questions.text: What is PACS in medical imaging?
questions.solution:
Picture archiving and communication system (PACS) is a modality of imaging technology that helps in image transmission from the site of acquisition of images, to multiple different sites at different locations.

This is not only economical (film-less department), but is also convenient to access multiple modalities (radiographs, CT, MRI, ultrasound) simultaneously at multiple locations within the hospital or across the globe.

Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine (DICOM) is a standard for handling, storing, printing, and transmitting information in medical imaging. DICOM is used worldwide to store, exchange, and transmit medical images.

questions.text: In a population of 5000, the birth rate is 30 per 1000 population. 15 children died in their first year of life and of those 9 died in their first month. What is the infant mortality rate in this population:
questions.solution:

  • In this scenario, the number of live births would be 150
  • Number of deaths of children under age 1 is 15
  • IMR = 100
  • IMR is regarded as the most important indicator of the health status of a community and of the effectiveness of MCH care
  • As of SRS bulletin 2018, Indian IMR is 32

Stage I - limited to the cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

questions.text: Verocay bodies are seen in:

questions.text: A person working in a farm developed multiple nodules along the lymphatics following rose thorn pick. Diagnosis is:

questions.text: A lady diagnosed with breast carcinoma underwent chemotherapy and reports hair loss after two weeks. What is this pattern of hair loss known as?
questions.solution:
Alopecia after chemotherapy is known as anagen effluvium. 

Hair loss following chemotherapy usually occurs within 1–3 weeks after initiation of the therapy. In this type of hair loss, the anagen phase is abruptly terminated. This leads to the loss of dystrophic or broken hairs and the condition is called anagen effluvium. The hair loss is acute and diffuse. However, there is full recovery within a few months of stopping the causative drug. 

The most important drugs implicated in the order of decreasing frequency of association causing anagen effluvium:

  1. Anti-microtubule agents (paclitaxel)
  2. Topo-isomerase inhibitors (doxorubicin)
  3. Alkylating agents (cyclophosphamide)
  4. Anti-metabolites (5-fluorouracil)

Other options:

Option A: Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory condition that causes non-scarring hair loss. It is caused by a T‐cell‐mediated autoimmune mechanism. The characteristic initial lesion is a smooth, circum­scribed patch of hair loss. Short, easily extractable broken hairs are seen at the margins of the patch, known as exclamation mark hairs.

Option B: Telogen effluvium refers to an increase in the shedding of telogen club hairs due to premature termination of the anagen phase. It is an acute‐onset hair loss. It usually occurs 2–3 months following a triggering event such as high fever, surgery, sudden starvation, or hemorrhage.

Option D: Telogen gravidarum refers to the telogen hair loss that occurs 2–3 months after childbirth.

Related Pearl: Hair Cycle

Hair follicles undergo a repetitive sequence of growth and the rest is known as the hair cycle. Hair Cycle is usually described under three phases: Anagen, Catagen, and Telogen.

1. Anagen

  • The period of active hair growth is known as anagen and the duration of this phase is responsible for determining the final length of the hair.
  • The entry of a resting hair follicle into anagen is heralded by the onset of mitotic activity in epithelial cells overlying the dermal papilla at the base of the follicle (the secondary epithelial germ).
  • Under normal circumstances, 80–90% of hair follicles on the human scalp are in anagen at any one time.
  • Anagen can continue for several years.

Fig 1. Scalp hair follicle in the anagen II stage of development

Fig 2.  Anagen hair bulb. Co, hair cortex; Cu, hair cuticle; DP, dermal papilla; DS, dermal sheath; He, Henle layer; HM, hair matrix; Hu, Huxley layer; IRSCu, inner root sheath cuticle; Me, melanocyte; ORS, outer root sheath

2. Catagen

  • At the end of anagen, epithelial cell division declines and ceases, and the follicle enters an involutionary phase known as catagen.
  • During catagen, the proximal end of the hair shaft keratinizes to form a club-shaped structure and the lower part of the follicle involutes by apoptosis.
  • The basement membrane surrounding the follicle becomes thickened and corrugated to form the ‘glassy membrane’.
  • It lasts for about 10 days.

Fig 3.  Human hair follicle in mid-catagen. There is a prominent glassy membrane surrounding the regressing epithelial column. The dermal papilla is rounded and condensed. 

3. Telogen

  • It is the time period between catagen and the next anagen.
  • It lasts for about 3 months.
  • Club hair is eventually shed through an active process called exogen.
  • In the human scalp, hair follicles may remain in a state of latency, also known as kenogen, for a pro­longed period after the club hair is shed.

Related Pearl: Causes of scarring and non-scarring alopecia- Mnemonic

  2. Scarring/Cicatricial alopecia

questions.text: Co infection is essential for disease presentation in:
questions.solution:
Hepatitis D or delta hepatitis needs co-infection with Hepatitis B for its presentation.

Hepatitis D virus (HDV) is an incomplete/defective virus. It requires HBV, to provide the envelope protein (HbsAg) to aid in its survival. 

Two types of infection may occur:  

  • Co-infection - acute HDV and HBV infections occur simultaneously
  • Super-infection - Delta viral infection occurs in a person already harboring HBV. This most often leads to chronic hepatitis

Coinfection and superinfection can cause fulminant hepatitis. HBV vaccination is protective against HDV.

questions.text: Polycystic kidney disease genes chromosomes are:
questions.solution:
APKD:

  • Due to mutation of PKD 1 gene (Chromosome 16) and PKD 2 gene (on chromosome 4)
  • PKD 1 and 2 genes encode for polycystin 1 and 2 proteins (and not genes) respectively

Autosomal dominant (adult) polycystic kidney disease is a hereditary disorder characterized by multiple expanding cysts of both kidneys that ultimately destroy the renal parenchyma and cause renal failure.

PKD1 gene is located on chromosome 16p13.3

  • It encodes a large (460-kD) integral membrane protein named polycystin-1, which has a large extracellular region, multiple transmembrane domains, and a short cytoplasmic tail.
  • Polycystin-1 is expressed in tubular epithelial cells, particularly those of the distal nephron.
  • It contains domains that are usually involved in cell-cell and cell-matrix interactions.
  • Mutations in PKD1 account for about 85% of cases.

PKD2 gene, located on chromosome 4q21, accounts for most of the remaining cases of the polycystic disease.

  • Its product, polycystin-2, is an integral membrane protein that is expressed in all segments of the renal tubules and in many extrarenal tissues.
  • Polycystin-2 functions as a Ca2+ - permeable cation channel.
  • Overall, the disease is less severe than that associated with PKD1 mutations.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, abdominal pain, and a recent history of diarrhea. He has associated tenderness over the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Abdominal CT is shown below. Which of the following drugs is indicated for the management of the CT finding?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a patient presenting with fever, abdominal pain, a recent history of diarrhea, and an abdominal CT showing a moderate-sized abscess in the right liver lobe is suggestive of an amebic liver abscess. It is an extra-intestinal infection caused by Entamoeba histolytica and metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating this condition. 

Amebic liver abscess follows intestinal amebiasis. However, a history of diarrhea may not always be present as most patients remain asymptomatic carriers. In patients presenting with the above symptoms, stool examination, serological tests, and radiological imaging help to confirm the diagnosis. 

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating invasive amebiasis like an amebic liver abscess. It is a nitroimidazole compound and is a highly active tissue amebicide. Tinidazole, which is another longer-acting imidazole, is also highly effective for the management of this condition. Other tissue amebicides include secnidazole, satranidazole and ornidazole.

Metronidazole is also effective against other anaerobic and microaerophilic organisms. It is used in the management of giardiasis, trichomoniasis, anaerobic bacterial infections (e.g., pelvic or abdominal abscesses following surgery), pseudomembranous enterocolitis, and Helicobacter pylori gastritis.

Adverse effects include gastrointestinal manifestations like anorexia, nausea, and a metallic taste. It is known for its ability to produce a disulfiram-like reaction when taken with alcohol. Metronidazole can decrease the renal elimination of lithium and potentiate its toxicity. It may also cause significant bleeding in patients on warfarin therapy.

Other options:

Iodoquinol (Option B), paromomycin (Option C), and diloxanide furoate (Option D) are luminal amebicides. They are poorly absorbed and thus reach high concentrations in the bowel and are used in the management of intestinal amebiasis. They are also indicated for invasive amebiasis. However, their role is to eradicate cysts and prevent further transmission. They would not have any direct effect on the extraintestinal liver abscess as seen in this case.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man from Kashmir presents with fever, chills and rash for 1 week. The rash appeared on the 5th day of the fever starting from the trunk and progressing to the limbs. Epidemic typhus is suspected. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the disease?

choices.text: Brill-Zinsser disease is a recrudescent form
Rash is present on palms and soles

questions.solution:
Epidemic typhus rash spares the palms and soles. 

Epidemic typhus, caused by Rickettsia prowazekii, is transmitted by the louse Pediculus humanus corporis. There is no transovarial transmission of R. prowazekii. The disease spreads through infected louse feces deposited when the louse feeds on the human host. It is commonly seen in poor unhygienic or cold conditions.

Epidemic typhus starts with fever and chills. A characteristic rash appears on the fourth or fifth day, starting on the trunk and spreading over the limbs but sparing the face, palms, and soles. In some patients who recover from epidemic typhus, the rickettsiae may remain latent in the lymphoid tissues or organs for years. Such latent infection may, at times, be reactivated leading to recrudescent typhus (Brill-Zinsser disease).

Transovarial transmission refers to passing on the disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod. It occurs with Orientia tsutsugamushi, Rickettsia rickettsii, R. conorii and R. akari.

Note: Rash on palms and soles is typically described in Rocky Mountain spotted fever, secondary syphilis and hand, foot, and mouth disease

The image below shows the rash of epidemic typhus.

questions.text: You suspect psoriatic erythroderma in a patient who presented with superficial scaling of the skin and redness. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for erythrodermic psoriasis is methotrexate. It is a folate antagonist that acts by the inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase. It inhibits lymphocyte proliferation and is thereby used in the management of generalized pustular psoriasis, psoriatic erythroderma and debilitating arthritis. 

Depending on the type of psoriasis, various therapeutic options are available: 

  • Topical agents - for psoriasis of limited extent
    • Coal tar
    • Dithranol
    • Tazarotene
    • Calcipotriol
    • Steroids
  • Systemic agents - for moderate to severe psoriasis
    • Methotrexate
    • Acitretin
    • Cyclosporin
  • Phototherapy
  • Biologicals
    • TNF-alpha inhibitors: Infliximab, Etanercept, Adalimumab
    • IL 12 / 23 inhibitor: Ustekinumab
    • Selective IL-23 inhibitor: Tildrakizumab
    • IL-17 inhibitors: Secukinumab, Brodalumab
    • Phosphodiesterase-4 inhibitors: Apremilast

The only indication of systemic steroids is generalized pustular psoriasis in pregnancy (impetigo herpetiformis).

Erythrodermic psoriasis can be precipitated by the irritant effect of topical therapy, withdrawal of steroids, systemic illness, alcoholism and ultraviolet radiation. The clinical characteristics of psoriasis are often lost. There is generalized involvement of the skin with severe itching and redness. It may be associated with hypo or hyperthermia, hypoalbuminemia, anemia, dehydration and high output cardiac failure.

The clinical picture is given below :

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

True Koebner's phenomenon In immune-mediated conditions

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus
False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum
     
Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Generalized granuloma annulare

Vitiligo

Psoriasis

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

questions.text: Perifascicular atrophy is seen in :
questions.solution:
Perifascicular atrophy is seen in Dermatomyositis.

Myofiber atrophy is accentuated at the edges of the fascicles.

Dermatomyositis:

  • Dermatomyositis is an immunologic disease in which damage to small blood vessels contributes to muscle injury.
  • Muscle biopsies of affected patients show infiltrates of mononuclear inflammatory cells that tend to be most pronounced in the perimysial connective tissue and around blood vessels.
  • Sometimes there is a distinctive pattern in which myofiber atrophy is accentuated at the edges of the fascicles— perifascicular atrophy.

Muscle biopsy findings in dermatomyositis-

Other options:

Option D: Toxic myopathies/Drug-induced myopathies are mainly linked to lipid-lowering agents like statins and glucocorticoids, causing muscle pain, weakness, and elevated CK levels. High-dose glucocorticoids can result in acute quadriplegic myopathy, while chronic use leads to proximal weakness with normal CK levels. Other drugs, such as amphophilic cationic and antimicrotubular agents, may also cause muscle toxicity, identifiable by autophagic vacuoles in muscle biopsies.
